ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to live virtual classes, there were short recorded lectures usually on grammar to watch before classes.
A 2 student to 1 teaching fellow discussion session for speaking practice.
Virtual lectures 4 days a week and a virtual clinic once a week that is more individual. One day of the week there is no class, but the day is used to complete a test for the corresponding lesson.
4/5 classes per week were live zoom lectures, and 1/5 per week was an asynchronous activity either by yourself or with a partner.
Live virtual lecture with discussion 4 days a week and 1 asynchronous day for online tests/quizzes.
4 days of synchronous lessons, 1 day with an asynchronous group project or lesson test
Asynchronous class time once a week, which was used for pair or group works.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic Japanese speaking, reading, and writing. Speaking > other skills.
new language, simple grammatical structure of Japanese
I learned basic grammar and speech in Japanese. I can now order in Japanese, introduce myself, and describe people and places.
Introduction to Japanese! We learned Hiragana, Katakana, many Kanji, sentence structure and grammar, vocab, and had a lot of speaking and writing practice.

Starting with no prior knowledge/experience with the Japanese language (or any other similar language), I learned so much from this course. I learned how to read and write Hiragana, Katakana, and numerous Kanji. I learned basic the Japanese sentence structure as well as how to conjugate verbs into the polite affirmative and negative present indicative and progressive, past indicative, future, and imperative forms. I can also now hold basic conversations in Japanese about food, family, school, activities, and other basic things.
Elementary Japanese
I was able to learn a lot of Japanese quickly. Although it was difficult to engage in the class through Zoom, I definitely know a lot more about Japanese culture and the language.
How to read Hiragana, Katakana, and about 60 Kanji characters. Can hold conversations in Japanese, count, and describe things like location, time, and appearances.
Japanese grammar, reading, speaking, writing, and listening.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In-class speaking and grammar/writing/reading as HW was a good set-up. Some assignments, especifically conversation shadowing, were very useful but over-done as they were repeated in HW, in class, and in clinic, which is too much in my opinion. Some assignments were auto-pilot and not very useful.
The strengths are the sheer number of assignments and coursework for the class that it keeps you engaged in the subject.
Japanese clinic was fun and helpful, and was useful to get another point of view for grammar explanations. The class was generally very good. I would've liked a lot more reading practice though.

This course is well structured and organized in a way that makes learning Japanese easier due to the way he lessons build upon each other in a way that works really well. The lectures are well taught and allow for practice speaking with breakout rooms with classmates. Homework always helps reinforce what's been taught and solidifies reading, writing, speaking, and grammar skills.

The strength of this course is Yamaguchi Sensei. She made sure that the work was challenging but also manageable and it was clear that she really wanted us to fully understand. She will push you to expand your vocabulary and your skill level. She was also very understanding when the class was tired. She gave us five minutes to talk freely and I genuinely appreciated and needed that.

Online aspects of the course were extremely well organized, facilitating learning and submitting assignments. Everyone was engaged in the class and Yamaguchi-Sensei is very passionate and caring about her students.

Between mandatory weekly clinics, homework, and (necessary!) review, there is more of a time commitment than anticipated that I wish I was aware of before taking the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The 4/1 synchronous/asynchronous classes was a good set-up. Good use of breakout rooms, however, often we would go over the hw/assignment much more quickly than the time allotted. Free talking was useful to do in this free-time but would be easier to do if there was a topic of discussion suggested. Making conversation through zoom in English is hard enough.
I personally think the class should have been more flexible considering the circumstances, yet it seemed like it was taught just like how it would normally be in an in-person seminar.

The classes and the Canvas page were incredibly well organized, it was very clear what we would be doing every day and what homework we had due. I think the class was about as well planned and executed as it could possibly have been online. Of the classes I took this semester it was the best adapted for the online format.

For this semester, this course was structured as a completely online course with 4 synchronous online lectures/discussions with one asynchronous day for working on group projects and/or completing tests or quizzes in the middle of the week. This adaption worked fairly well in my opinion. Synchronous  days and homework were ( I assume) pretty similar to how the in person version of this course would have been conducted, except the lessons were over zoom with breakout rooms used to practice speaking Japanese and homework was taken a picture of and submitted as a pdf online.  The tests/quizzes on asynchronous days were conducted via a timed test on Canvas with both multiple choice, fill in the blank, and open response questions. These were perhaps more difficult that they would have been in person because of difficultly scrolling between the reading passage and questions and typing instead of just writing Hiragana/Kanji. Overall, this course was very engaging even though it was online and the only improvement I would suggest is streamlining test/quiz structure online on Canvas.
It was helpful to reinforce what we learned by reviewing homework. I believe that there should be more group projects in order to encourage more conversation among classmates.

The Canvas website for the class was extremely well organized and made online lessons and assignments very clear-cut. In class, we were put into breakout rooms to practice activities before returning to the main room to repeat and solidify concepts in front of the class. The breakout rooms definitely helped make classmates more comfortable around each other.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in Japanese, this is a great course for beginners, especially absolute beginners. If you have studied a bit of Japanese already on your own, I would recommend trying to self-study to the point where you can place into L3/L4.
This course taught me so much in such a short amount of time, I definitely think its worth it!
Absolutely! This was an awesome language course and I would recommend it to anyone who wanted to learn Japanese, or anyone who is unsure what language they want to learn.

Yes! This was a wonderful introductory course to the Japanese language. It is well taught and well organized, Yamaguchi-sensei is truly a wonderful teacher. It is quite intensive (hence it being 1.5 credits) and there is a good amount of homework and quizzes every week, but it never feels like work just for the sake of work and you learn an incredible amount in a short amount of time. I started with absolutely no background/experience in Japanese or any other similar languages, and after one semester I hold basic conversations and can read and write Hiragana and Katakana, as well as many Kanji. I cannot recommended this course enough for those interested in learning Japanese.
If you're interested in learning Japanese, yes. It helps to drill the basics of hiragana, katakana, and some kanji before going into L2.

Yes, as long as you are passionate about learning Japanese. Even if you know zero Japanese words prior to taking the course, you will be able to read and hold long conversations confidently by the end of the semester. It's very satisfying to track the immense progress made in such a short period of time.
